image.altText: A woman looks sternly at the camera.

props.synopsis: Crystal's baby was born in jail while she waited for her case to be processed. Her wait for justice is not uncommon in the NT, where the courts are so backlogged that unprecedented numbers of people are being left to languish on remand.

title.children: Crystal's newborn son spent his first 10 months in prison, while she waited almost a year on remand

image.altText: Close up of a woman and a young girl

props.synopsis: A Qantas flight from Perth to the Pilbara region was diverted to Geraldton due to a mechanical issue. A passenger onboard says they were "terrified" and called for aircraft used on the route to be replaced.

title.children: Passengers message loved ones during 'terrifying' Qantas flight in regional WA

image.altText: Mad flats in the foreground and a land mass in the distanced, with water between them.

props.synopsis: Saibai Islanders say they have been left to "fend for themselves" as confrontations over illegal fishing expose flaws in border security, putting their livelihoods and safety at risk.

title.children: This tiny stretch of water separates Australia from PNG — locals say it's a major security risk

image.altText: a photo of a man in a suit speaking with a building in the background

props.synopsis: As the NT government brings tough new public drinking measures to parliament, an independent politician is urging Aboriginal people sleeping rough to consider leaving town centres.

title.children: Aboriginal politician warns people sleeping rough to go bush or risk jailtime under tough new laws

image.altText: Bruce Simpson

props.synopsis: Inquiry chair Joshua Creamer says it is about unity while the LNP leader says he will stop it because he does not want a repeat of the "division" of last year's Voice referendum.

title.children: Mayor of Aboriginal community says inquiry chance to 'hear our truth' as LNP stands by scrapping it, if elected

image.altText: A baby crocodile on some grass.

props.synopsis: Remote residents were taken aback when they discovered a baby crocodile in a woman's front yard on the weekend.

title.children: Baby crocodile walks 2km to remote Aboriginal community in search of water

image.altText: Man in orange basketball singlet lays up shot

props.synopsis: The Darwin Salties have become just the latest NT sports club to bite the dust, after quitting the NBL1 North basketball competition for financial reasons. It comes as the NT continues its push to join the AFL.

title.children: What the demise of a popular Darwin basketball club could mean for the NT's AFL team bid

image.altText: Three men address the media.

props.synopsis: The NT government has revealed plans to permanently transfer children from Alice Springs youth detention to Darwin as part of an "emergency response" aimed at rolling out a thousand new prison beds over the next four years.

title.children: Alice Springs youth to be relocated to Darwin as part of NT government's 'emergency' prisons plan

image.altText: Indigenous AFL players pose together for a photo

props.synopsis: A decade-long wait is over as the AFL announced the Indigenous All-Stars will play a fixture in the pre-season next year. The squad is poised to be one of the most talented football teams to ever set foot on a ground.

title.children: The AFL's Indigenous All-Stars are back after a decade in the wilderness, and the amount of talent they could put out on the field is frightening

image.altText: King Charles at Sydney Opera House royal tour

props.synopsis: The royal couple met enthusiastic crowds at Sydney Opera House after a busy day attending a community barbecue in Parramatta, fit with sheepdogs and sausage sandwiches.

title.children: King Charles III and Queen Camilla have finished their Australian royal tour. Here's the big moments from their final day

image.altText: The exterior of the Alice Springs Local Court building.

props.synopsis: An inquest into the death of a toddler, who fell into a septic tank in a remote Central Australian community last year, has heard about a string of departmental failures to address safety risks at the site.

title.children: Inquest into toddler's septic tank death hears infrastructure department 'ignored' safety risks

image.altText: Xi Jinping and Narendra Modi waive at the camera while standing in front of Indian and Chinese flags respectively

props.synopsis: Troops from China and India have been involved in a tense stand-off for years high in the Himalayas, but a new deal raises the prospect of a peaceful future.

title.children: Two nuclear-armed states have been involved in a bitter stand-off for years. Could a new deal guarantee peace?

image.altText: New Indonesian ministers salute during their inauguration

props.synopsis: Mugiyanto thought he would die after being abducted by soldiers in 1998 when Prabowo Subianto was a powerful special forces commander. Now the former human rights advocate has joined the Indonesian president's cabinet.

title.children: Prabowo's 'fat cabinet' features active military members — and an activist kidnapped by the military

image.altText: A man with blond hair wearing a suit looks into the distance

props.synopsis: The 80-year-old is accused of baiting young men with the prospect of modelling jobs so they could be abused.

title.children: Former Abercrombie & Fitch CEO arrested on US sex trafficking charges

image.altText: Older indigenous men stand behind a wide gate labelled Kinchela Boys Home

props.synopsis: The 49 Indigenous survivors from Kinchela Boys Home want to turn the site into a museum and place of healing as they mark 100 years since the institution began operations.

title.children: Stripped naked, heads shaved and given a number to replace their name. Survivors of boys home share their stories

image.altText: A group of about twenty people dressed all in black with their faces covered.

props.synopsis: Police have used capsicum spray on a group of far-right protesters who disrupted an asylum seeker rally in Melbourne's Docklands last night.

title.children: Police use capsicum spray on far-right protesters after clash at asylum seeker rally

image.altText: Drone image of wind turbines on coastline.

props.synopsis: Tasmania is headed for a 15-year low in its renewable energy generation — posing a threat to the state's claim of being "100 per cent renewable".

title.children: Green energy boast looking shaky with fossil fuels, electricity imports in Tasmania's mix

image.altText: Two young school children walk towards school carrying colourful backpacks.

props.synopsis: The Australian Bureau of Statistics says the number of families in Australia has gone up by a million in a decade, but it is couples who are more likely to live without dependants.

title.children: Five graphs reveal how Australian families are working in 2024

image.altText: A large boat sails through blue waters

props.synopsis: The drills come a week after China launched a one-day exercise that it said aimed at practising "sealing off key ports and key areas".

title.children: China holds live-fire drills near Taiwan a week after encircling the island in another military exercise

image.altText: Kamala Harris and Donald Trump looking at each other in election illustration

props.synopsis: The Central Park Five announce they're suing Donald Trump for defamation and Kamala Harris courts the Republican vote — here's the latest updates from the US election.

title.children: Walz says Trump 'spiralling' as former president hit with new lawsuit — the latest from the US election campaign

image.altText: A woman with blond hair looks sideways

props.synopsis: Yulia Navalnaya vows to take on Vladimir Putin, saying she will return to Russia and run for president when he is no longer in power.

title.children: Alexei Navalny's exiled widow says she will run for Russian presidency after Putin

image.altText: Lidia Thorpe protest

props.synopsis: The fallout from Lidia Thorpe’s message to the king has made global headlines. But what do Indigenous Australians make of the interaction? From 'Not really accurate' to 'very ballsy' First Nations people weight in.

title.children: 'We've put down our spears, we’re using our voice': Mob react to Lidia Thorpe

image.altText: Girl with blurred face dancing in a red tutu with elaborate gold embroidery

props.synopsis: A dance teacher tells a court a teenager whose parents are accused of starving her was at risk of fractures if she jumped too much, but the parents refused her pleas to get medical assistance for their daughter.

title.children: Teacher who raised alarm about teen with 'wafer thin' arms says parents brushed off concerns

image.altText: A group of dancers smile, standing together with Aboriginal face paint, holding gum leaves.

props.synopsis: A new public holiday and more oversight of government spending on Indigenous affairs are among the ideas being taken into Victoria's treaty negotiations later this year.

title.children: Public holiday celebrating Aboriginal culture to be proposed in Victoria's treaty negotiations

image.altText: Artist Hossei in his colourful studio. He has long black hair and holds up the album cover showing his mum's face

props.synopsis: Sydney artist HOSSEI creates musical starring his mum: “She's this 70-year-old ethnic woman that I just don't see in the arts, so I really wanted to give her a voice.”

title.children: People like HOSSEI's mum are rarely seen on stage. So, he wrote her a 'Persian pop musical'

image.altText: baby formula being put into bottle

props.synopsis: The federal government will establish a mandatory code of conduct to oversee the way baby formula products are advertised in Australia.

title.children: New rules for baby formula advertisements aim to protect parents

image.altText: A boy tackles another boy holding the football while playing a game

props.synopsis: When 11-year-old Henri was hit on the head by a basketball, it began a 12-month medical ordeal.

title.children: What happens when developing brains sustain a concussion

image.altText: The arms and torso of a patient with skin lesions

props.synopsis: An infection with the new mpox variant clade 1b is detected in Germany for the first time. It's the second case of this variant to be reported in Europe after a severe outbreak in Africa earlier this year raised alarm.

title.children: Germany detects first case of new mpox variant linked to outbreak in Africa

image.altText: gold bar

props.synopsis: A modern-day gold rush has moved up a gear with the price of the precious metal breaking records, as observers, including the Reserve Bank deputy, warn broader financial markets may have gotten ahead of themselves.

title.children: Gold price goes 'a bit nuts' but have financial markets got ahead of themselves?

image.altText: A man at a podium in an empty auditorium.

props.synopsis: Graduating students say a speech by former union boss Joe de Bruyn "took a hard-right turn" as he voiced anti-abortion views during a ceremony at the Australian Catholic University in Melbourne.

title.children: Students walk out during 'shocking' anti-abortion speech by former union boss at university graduation

image.altText: Police tape over street

props.synopsis: Cars, tobacco and cash are seized as part of raids across Victoria linked to an organised crime syndicate that police investigators allege earned $30 million over 12 months selling illegal tobacco.

title.children: Lamborghini and 600,000 cigarettes seized as police lay federal charges in raids on illegal tobacco syndicate

image.altText: Bridge under construction

props.synopsis: Crews are working to rectify a "problem" identified during the ongoing construction of a new $786 million bridge north of Hobart, which has resulted in two parts of the structure not lining up — but the Tasmanian government is adamant it won't cause delays or cost money.

title.children: Bridgewater Bridge 'problem' won't cause delay or cost money, Tasmanian government says

image.altText: Images of brain scans.

props.synopsis: Both these conditions are rising globally at a rapid rate and have a deep and profound impact on those diagnosed.

title.children: Genetic variants linked to ADHD and Parkinson's, Queensland led study on brain size finds

image.altText: Two feet stuck between two large boulders.

props.synopsis: Photographs have emerged of the remarkable rescue of Matilda Campbell, 23, who fell three metres into a rock crevice in the NSW Hunter Valley earlier this month.

title.children: Images show dramatic rescue of woman left hanging by feet for seven hours after attempt to retrieve phone
